No, this isn't canon. In our history, Boudica was stripped and publicly flogged with a cat o' nine tails; she was not raped as August's law forbade sex with a widow. Roman soldiers did however rape her two daughters as an act of blasphemy against the Britons' Iceni gods. The queen's daughters would further be viewed as impure and demoralise the Britons against committing further acts of rebellion. The Fate storyline maintains this version of the story.

Demoralization- implant into the soft minds of a new generation marxist/Leninist ideas and have it spread towards the rest of academia. They will then spread those ideas amongst themselves and their children eventually becoming a cycle that requires no more input from the subverter. Next is destabilization- the fall of the essentials, economy, foreign relations, defense systems (police and military). Next is crisis- a country crippling event that will allow the subverter to take over the country leading to the next stage, normalization- usually ends with getting rid of those who helped put the current system in power by lining them up against a wall because they already know too much. This will be teachers, journalists, civil rights groups and the ideologically subverted who were basically the foot soldiers that led the charge. Then you will be done and achieve a state of your normalcy in the taken over country.

Subversion brought chaos, chaos led to destabilization. Frighteningly similar to what's going on today, so similar that I'd say it's uncanny. Once a great nation/empire is sufficiently weakened from within, once the body's own immune system stops caring and gives in, it becomes ripe for the pickings, and the long list of enemies, usurpers, demons, monsters and the wicked make their move. Cue the barbarians, the hun mongols, the arabs and their cousins doing what they do/did best, no longer having to wait, no longer having to contain their true intentions, with no time to wipe their grotesque, filthy, salivating mouths, the move in for the kill, the rape, the pillage and the subversion + usury. Sand goblins for far away lands now installing and naming themselves "nobles" on other peoples homes. And you know the rest of this crude, vile and bloody story of this forsaken world.

@Vex-Hex Comparing Romans to Nazis is facile. Roman brutality, unlike Nazi brutality, was completely normalized for its context. Classical antiquity was horrific to an extent that is difficult for modern people to conceive of; the entire political economy of the ancient Mediterranean was inherently, inextricably rooted in slave raiding, which required the routine massacre of outlying peoples, then ripping captives from their families and selling them into exploitative forced labor. Much of this labor, like in mines and mills, meant an early death sentence by overwork, and being sold into prostitution or domestic labor often meant a life spent being raped over and over again. And remember, the ENTIRE ECONOMY was totally dependent on this!

In fact I'm actually surprised that there aren't many rape/bdsm/ntr fetish doujins which take inspiration from classical history. Probably because popular history and history education shies away from talking about this stuff.
